@pldash Can you remind me again what the usecase is?

@chavdar This is to skip reading the previous workunits when we are trying to do a full load regularly and the source file is always the same. Every day the same file is updated with the latest snapshot.
Just glanced through it. Seems like a lot of file. Can I review it in the next InDay?

@sahilTakiar I don't like the idea of such an option. This looks a big gun for people to shoot themselves in the foot. I don't see a reason to ignore the previous state. 

In this particular case, actually I think it is a short-coming of how state is stored currently for the FileBasedSource . The file name is not sufficient. We also need the file modification timestamp. Then the source should compare both names and timestamps of previously processed files and currently existing files.

One possible approach is to
- Define a class TimestampedFile contains of a file path string and a long last modification timestamp
- Define equals(), hashValue() in the natural way using both the path and the timestamp.
- A TimestampedFile is serialized to a string as a "<path>:::<timestamp>". 
- Similarly, a TimestampedFile can be created for the above string. For backwards compatibility, if :::<timestamp> is missing, we can assume 0 timestamp.
- ReUse the existing SOURCE_FILEBASED_FS_SNAPSHOT property but make it a list the string serializations of TimestampedFile
- getcurrentFsSnapshot() should return a Collection<TimestampedFile>
- When computing filesToPull we should use a HashSet instead of the current List to make removeAll() efficient.
- If we define TimestampedFile.equals() as above, the removeAll() will do the right thing and keep a file for pulling if the name has remained the same but the modification timestamp has changed.

Agreed, didn't realize that was the use case.

I think you can also delete `this.jobContext.getJobState().setEndTime(workflowContext.getFinishTime());` since it is set again later on: https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/blob/8fb95bfe27e67cdcdd84ec41d79d2e84b719cb18/gobblin-runtime/src/main/java/gobblin/runtime/AbstractJobLauncher.java#L311

Actually, I'm not sure how this is going to solve the scenario where Azkaban executes a SLA kill on the job. Looking at `MRJobLauncher.cancelJob` only tries to kill the Hadoop job, but doesn't try to cancel anything else like the `Publisher` or `StateStore` serialization. So if `cancelJob` is invoked while the alias is created, the alias creation will probably continue to run until Azkaban just invokes a `kill -9` on the process. And we will just hit the same `EOFException`.

Any ideas? If we could use a RDMS instead I feel like DB transactions would make this a lot easier.

@chavdar Is it really required to create a new class TimestampedFile. We can just get the list of files along with modified time in the currentFsSnapshot. Finally after removing the prevFsSnapshot we can split the name to pick out only the filename.

@ibuenros @sahilTakiar I've updated this with the ability to specify four different port ranges.  They all are "strict" in that if a port cannot be found the application will crash.

The tokens are:
1. `${PORT_1234}` : Try to get port 1234 and fail if it is not available
2. `${PORT_?1234}`: Try to get any port from the minimum port (1025) inclusive to the specified port inclusive.
3. `${PORT_1234?}`: Try to get any port from the specified port inclusive to the maximum port (65535) inclusive
4. `${PORT_?}`: Try to get a random port between the minimum port (1025) inclusive and the maximum port (65535) inclusive

@sahilTakiar: All outstanding comments are addressed.
What's the difference between `gobblin.data.management.hive.HiveRegistrableDataset` and `gobblin.hive.policy.HiveRegistrationPolicy`?
Can you add a description of what this PR entails?

`HiveRegistrableDataset` is not currently used, and I'm not sure if it's needed. Conceptually it is a `Dataset` that contains a set of `HiveSpec`s. `HiveRegistrationPolicy` contains the logic to generate `HiveSpec`s for a specific path.

High Level Comment:
- Anyway we can get this to run via `TestNG` and not via Azkaban?
  - The current implementation seems to require running a job via Azkaban, which means these tests won't run unless someone manually uploads the job to Azkaban and runs them.
  - However, while these are integration tests I don't see anything that requires them to be run on Azkaban or in a real HDFS cluster, it could simply be run on top of the local file system (e.g. `FileSystem.getLocal()`
- The advantage would be that these tests get run during each build, which will help us catch any unexpected bugs earlier

Just throwing out ideas, but it may be better to separate the source of the configs from the deployment / rollback of the configs. An interface `ConfigSource` can have implementations like `ClasspathConfigSource`, etc. The `Deployable.deploy` method just takes in streams of data and is solely responsible for writing the data out. `StoreDeployer` ties the two interfaces together.

@sahilTakiar I think your suggestion for decoupling `ConfigSource` and Deployment makes sense. I think having an instance of `ConifgSource` inside of `DeploymentConfig` is better. The `Deployable.deploy(DeploymentConfig)` will get call `DeploymentConfg.ConfigSource.getConfigsPath()` which will return a  `Set<String>` of source path either from classpath or somewhere else.

LGTM other than one comment. Please use a more meaningful commit message.

In general, unit tests should be used for testing a single component in isolation. Dependencies should be mocked or use simplified test versions.

Integration tests should use multiple realistic components potentially running on different Hadoop clusters. Eventually, we may have the tooling to setup one or more local Hadoop clusters for testing but we don't have that right now. Loading a test on Azkaban and running it there should be a temp solution.

What this PR is missing is a high-level description of how the integration test framework is working. It seems like RegressionTest is the input point but I am still trying to figure this out.
Do these tests rely on manual deployment of the config files on HDFS? If yes, we should integrate it with the config deployment code.

Is there a concrete use case for providing a `SKIP` option? I'm ok with just always having the job fail if the lock is already in use. This way its not possible for a user to shoot themselves in the foot by setting `job.lock.denied.behavior=SKIP` and later realize that even though the job ran it didn't do anything.
Can you also change the title of this PR to something like `Adding Parallelization to WorkUnit Creation in KafkaSource`

Yes.  If we schedule a job to run every 15 minutes and it takes longer than 15 minutes, a failure will be logged to the history DB.  Additionally, if we want to run the job "constantly" we schedule it to run once a minute.  This ensures that we process "constantly", but can cause a huge number of job failures to be recorded in the history DB.

I believe there are several ways to properly deal with the problems that can arise from the lock.  These are important whether skipping is enabled or not.  First, the job lock should require a heartbeat so that jobs that have crashed, frozen, or had machine die don't prevent the system from making progress.  Second, there should be metrics which indicate the number of job which are skipped or failed within a given unit of time.  This can be used to raise an alert to indicate that a problem exists with the job.  Third, the job run time can also be used to determine if there is a fundamental problem with the job in regards to the schedule and the amount of work to be done.  Lastly, SLAs can be use to determine if the job is healthy and processing correctly.
@sahilTakiar I looked at this again and I think I can accomplish my goals without the new setting.  I'll update the PR in a few.
